actualResults.title: OS Command Injection via Backtick Command Substitution
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - This is not a separate vulnerability but rather a documented exploitation technique/variant of the main command injection vulnerability. While the expected finding implies this vector exists, it was explicitly documented separately, showing comprehensive exploitation coverage.

actualResults.title: OS Command Injection via $() Command Substitution
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - This is a documented exploitation technique/variant showing the penetration tester's thorough analysis of command injection vectors. The expected finding did not explicitly list this, though it's a variation of the core vulnerability.

actualResults.title: Blind OS Command Injection via Time-Based Detection
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - This documents a specific exploitation scenario using timing inference channels. The expected finding mentions the 'blind nature' of the vulnerability, and this finding provides detailed evidence and methodology for exploiting blind injection through timing analysis.

actualResults.title: OS Command Injection via IFS (Internal Field Separator) Manipulation
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - This documents an advanced filter-evasion technique using shell variable manipulation. While not explicitly listed in the expected findings, this represents thorough vulnerability analysis by the penetration tester exploring bypass techniques for basic input validation.

matched.actualTitle: OS Command Injection via Semicolon Separator + Backtick Substitution + $() Substitution + Timing-Based Detection + IFS Manipulation
matched.matchReason: All 5 actual findings are different exploitation vectors of the same underlying command injection vulnerability. They all target the ip_address parameter in the /ping endpoint, demonstrate unfiltered user input leading to arbitrary OS command execution, have identical impact (RCE, system compromise), and stem from the same root cause (subprocess.Popen with unsanitized user input). The actual findings provide comprehensive documentation of multiple attack vectors for the single expected vulnerability.
